unnormalised: Okay, so I'm trying to figure out if my address is ridiculously complicated or if everyone else's is just pretending theirs makes sense. Seriously, does anyone else feel like they're writing a riddle when giving directions?
normalised: Okay, so I am trying to figure out if my address is ridiculously complicated or if everyone else's is just pretending theirs makes sense. Seriously, does anyone else feel like they are writing a riddle when giving directions?

unnormalised: My current address looks something like this: "H. No. 12-34/A/B, 2nd Floor, Above Ganesh Medicals, Near the Big Banyan Tree, Opp. Axis Bank ATM, Beside Sai Temple Lane, Chandanagar, Hyderabad, Telangana, 500050." I swear, Iâ€™m missing a landmark... perhaps a stray cow or a particularly grumpy paanwala?
normalised: My current address looks something like this: "H. No. twelve divided by thirty four slash A slash B, second Floor, Above Ganesh Medicals, Near the Big Banyan Tree, Opposite Axis Bank A-T-M, Beside Sai Temple Lane, Chandanagar, Hyderabad, Telangana, five hundred thousand and fifty." I swear, I am missing a landmark... perhaps a stray cow or a particularly grumpy paanwala?

unnormalised: The "H. No. 12-34/A/B" part is where the fun begins. What does that even mean? Did they run out of single-digit numbers and decide to get creative with fractions and alphabets? It feels like I'm solving a cryptic crossword clue just to find my own house. And the "2nd Floor, Above Ganesh Medicals" bit? Okay, helpful, but what if Ganesh Medicals moves? Am I suddenly living on the 1st floor or worse, become ground floor adjacent? The anxiety is REAL!
normalised: The "H. No. twelve divided by thirty four slash A slash B" part is where the fun begins. What does that even mean? Did they run out of single-digit numbers and decide to get creative with fractions and alphabets? It feels like I am solving a cryptic crossword clue just to find my own house. And the "second Floor, Above Ganesh Medicals" bit? Okay, helpful, but what if Ganesh Medicals moves? Am I suddenly living on the first floor or worse, become ground floor adjacent? The anxiety is R-E-A-L!

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on "Near the Big Banyan Tree." Which big banyan tree? There are like, 7 in a 5km radius. Are we talking about the one with the tire swing, the one with the love declarations carved into its trunk, or the one where the pigeons hold their daily parliament? This is crucial information, people!
normalised: And don't even get me started on "Near the Big Banyan Tree." Which big banyan tree? There are like, seven in a five kilometer radius. Are we talking about the one with the tire swing, the one with the love declarations carved into its trunk, or the one where the pigeons hold their daily parliament? This is crucial information, people!

unnormalised: Then we have "Opp. Axis Bank ATM." Yes, the ever-reliable ATM, a beacon of financial hope and a directional landmark. Until, of course, a new bank decides to set up shop, leaving me geographically displaced and directionally challenged. Thanks, capitalism!
normalised: Then we have "Opposite Axis Bank A-T-M." Yes, the ever-reliable A-T-M, a beacon of financial hope and a directional landmark. Until, of course, a new bank decides to set up shop, leaving me geographically displaced and directionally challenged. Thanks, capitalism!

unnormalised: "Beside Sai Temple Lane" adds another layer of intrigue. Is it the lane leading *to* the Sai Temple, or just a lane somewhere next to it? The ambiguity is killing me! And finally, the pincode, 500050, my one true friend in this address adventure, the only consistently reliable piece of information.
normalised: "Beside Sai Temple Lane" adds another layer of intrigue. Is it the lane leading to the Sai Temple, or just a lane somewhere next to it? The ambiguity is killing me! And finally, the pincode, five hundred thousand and fifty, my one true friend in this address adventure, the only consistently reliable piece of information.

unnormalised: Seriously, I feel like my address is a choose-your-own-adventure book. "If you see the auto-rickshaw stand, turn left. If you smell biryani, you've gone too far. If you encounter a philosophical goat, you're definitely lost."
normalised: Seriously, I feel like my address is a choose-your-own-adventure book. "If you see the auto-rickshaw stand, turn left. If you smell biryani, you have gone too far. If you encounter a philosophical goat, you are definitely lost."

unnormalised: So, tell me, am I alone in this residential address chaos? Or is everyone else navigating a similar labyrinth of landmarks, numerical codes, and existential questions? Please, share your most ridiculously complicated addresses. Misery loves company, and maybe we can create a collective map of confusing Indian addresses.
normalised: So, tell me, am I alone in this residential address chaos? Or is everyone else navigating a similar labyrinth of landmarks, numerical codes, and existential questions? Please, share your most ridiculously complicated addresses. Misery loves company, and maybe we can create a collective map of confusing Indian addresses.
